feed.title: Less is better: Repaving my MacBook Pro
feed.subtitle: John Lam on software

entry.title: Repaving my MacBook Pro
entry.summary:
I somehow managed to pooch my install of Mac OS X on my MacBook Pro today. I was seeing unusually high kernel CPU usage (> 50% on both cores) so I started uninstalling various things. At some point during this process Mac OS refused to boot.

No problem, I booted into Safe Boot mode copied my Parallels image to an external USB drive, popped in my recovery DVDs and reinstalled the OS in about an hour or so.

But the coolest thing is that it saved all of my application settings, and my apps came across as well – Virtue, QuickSilver, Adium, you name it – it just worked.

I’m waiting for the OS to patch itself via Software Update and I’m going to copy my Parallels image back and I’m back in business.

Repaving Windows was never this easy (believe me I have lots of experience here :).

Update: Everything is working perfectly now. And boy does it run a lot cooler now that the CPUs aren’t burning cycles in kernel mode anymore.
